dc:dc.dc:title: Native American Performance Group at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 3 x 4 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Handwritten on envelope: ''#2033 JCRS lent by Leon Newman Patient 10812''.

A Native American group performance at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. It was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside Denver.
Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center (JCRS).

dc:dc.dc:title: Bell Tailors' 1927 Annual Picnic
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item photograph, 10 x 44 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Printed on the front of the photograph: ''Bell Tailors' Annual Picnic, - Bergen Park, - Monday, July 18, 1927.'' On the back of the photograph: ''#1005A (oversize), Bell Tailors 1927.''

Bell Tailors' employees and their families picnic in Bergen Park in the Colorado mountains on July 18, 1927. People are holding three signs: ''Bell Tailors Annual Picnic, Bergen Park.'' There are five open-sided tour buses and some of the people are standing on top of one of the buses.
Donated by Rae Katz.
dc:dc.dc:creator: Mile High Photo Company (Denver, Colo.)

dc:dc.dc:title: Shwayder Family
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 6 x 7 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in Jeanne E. Abrams, Images of America: Jewish Denver, 1859-1940 (Charleston: Arcadia, 2007), 35.

Caption from photo book: ''The Shwayder Family celebrating the 80th birthday of Rachel Shwayder, seated center, at the Green Gables country Club, Denver, c. 1950. In 1910 Jesse Shwayder opened a small luggage factroy and with his brothers, Mark, Maurice, Benjamin, and Solomon, turned it into one of the largest luggage producers in America, the Samsonite Corporation. Leaders in Denver philanthropy, the Shwayder family took an especially active role in Rose Hospital, the University of Denver, the Denver Art Museum, the National Jewish Hospital, Temple Emanuel, and many other organizations. Courtesy: Mr. and Mrs. King Shwayder, Sponsor: Mr. and Mrs. King Shwayder.''
The Shwayder family pose on a stairway at the Green Gables Country Club during Rachel Shwayder's 80th birthday celebration.
Donated by Hannah Shwayder Berry
ph481

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Young Girls Playing at National Jewish Hospital
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Jewish children
Jews
Medical centers
Group homes for children
Denver Sheltering Home for Jewish Children
Jewish National Home for Asthmatic Children in Denver
National Home for Jewish Children in Denver
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four girls in dresses sit on the lawn at National Jewish Hospital for Consumptives in Denver, Colorado. Three girls are playing with toys, while one is sewing. The National Jewish Hospital (NJH) worked to prevent tuberculosis by accepting children who seemed susceptible to the disease, while offering good nutrition and plenty of fresh air to keep them healthy. The hospital was founded in 1899.
Title supplied by archivist. ||Appears in ''Images of America, Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 78.

dc:dc.dc:title: Portrait of Fannie Anfenger
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 20.
On back of photograph: ''#362 Fannie Anfenger about 1905 daughter of Louis Anfenger Donor Marjorie Hornbein acquired 11/80''. On envelope: ''#362 Fannie Anfenger, c 1905''.

Formal head and shoulders portrait of Fannie Anfenger (1885-1965) as a young woman wearing a lace dress and elaborate necklace. Fannie Anfenger was the daughter of Louis and Louise Schlesinger Anfenger. She married Sidney Rinds and they had one son, Louis Rinds.
Donated by Marjorie Hornbein.

dc:dc.dc:title: Fried Family Portrait
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 10 x 8 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 41.
On back of photograph: ''#1064 Kate, Bela and Eugene Fried, Bertha, Mary, Sally Fried''. On envelope: ''#1064 Fried's Framing and Gift Shop 1900-40s''.

Members of the Fried family stand in front of the Fried's Picture Frame Factory in Denver, Colorado. Kate, Bela and Eugene Fried are standing behind an iron fence while Bela and Kate's daughters, Bertha, Mary and Sally are in front of the fence. A large sign reads, ''Fried's Picture Frame Factory, Frames Made to Order, 4 cents a foot and up, Come In and See Our Stock''.
Donated by Bobbi Furer, daughter of Sally Fried.

dc:dc.dc:title: Founders of the Denver Sheltering Home for Jewish Children
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 87.

Handwritten on envelope: ''#1134 Founders of Denver Sheltering Home c 1907 (Fannie Lorber, Bessie Willen, etc.)''. The women are identified on the back of a National Jewish Medical and Research Center note card as, from left to right, Jennie Kantrowitz, Mollie Lifshutz, Bessie Willens, Mary Augenblich, Fannie Lorber, and Mrs. S. Disraelly. [The last woman is misidentified as S. Disraelly and should be Sadie Francis.]

Promotional note card from National Jewish Medical and Research Center showing the founders of the Denver Sheltering Home for Jewish Children. From left to right are Jennie Kantrowitz, Mollie Lifshutz, Bessie Willens, Mary Augenblich, Fannie Lorber and Sadie Francis. The Denver Sheltering Home for Jewish Children was founded in 1907 to care for children whose parents were victims of tuberculosis. It later evolved into the National Home for Asthmatic Children and eventually merged with National Jewish Hospital. Spearheaded by Fannie Lorber and Bessie Willens and other immigrant East European Jewish women, the home provided a traditional Jewish environment for the children who passed through its doors, as well as a strong secular education.
Created by National Jewish Hospital as part of their Centennial Celebration.

dc:dc.dc:title: Mosko Family
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 3 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 103.

Caption from photo book: ''Mrs. Ida Mosko and children who were born in the United States: left to right, Aaron, Ruth (Handler), Maurice, and Joseph, c. 1917., Jacob Mosko, a blacksmith, arrived in Denver in 1905 and within a few years sent for his wife and the six children who had been born in Europe., Courtesy: The Mosko Family.''
Mrs. Ida Mosko stands with her children, left to right, Aaron, Ruth, Maurice, and Joseph posing for a formal portrait.
